title: Ligatures
content:
Hello Steph, and Typophiles around here.   
   
 I am searching for some Ligatures ideas for some fonts that i am working on, searching on the web, i cant find a complete (i mean all the posibilities) spec book or something like that.   
   
 Any Information links about it are wellcome, or pdf files. Ok? Thanks a lot.   
   
MH
author: anonymous

comments.content:
Coincidence: I was about to start a thread in general discussions on this very topic.   
   
I purchased a license to Mrs. Eaves almost as soon as it came out, and I haven't regretted it for one second. There are some [beautifully inventive ligatures](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.emigre.com/EF.php?fid=142) in there (the "g" combinations are wicked!). And it works both in display and text settings.   
   
 [Cholla Unicase](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.emigre.com/dp/getfontpage.php?PChoUL.html) is a fine example of ligatures in a very contemporary setting, and understandably also ships with [Just van Rossum](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.emigre.com/dp/getfontpage.php?PChoUL.html)'s LigatureMaker.

Basically, there is no "complete listing": you can take it as far as you want to. The ct, st, and sp for example are not in use anymore because, due to changing in tastes, most people today find them disruptive in the flow of reading. The sz has been thrown out of modern German, and I haven't seen many examples using the ft and fft-ligatures in Petr van Blokland's Proforma yet.   
   
I'll try to post a couple of examples later on.

Don't forget Eplica   
 [http://www.veer.com/results.asp?image=LFT3020130#about](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.veer.com/results.asp?image=LFT3020130#about)   
   
and Classica   
 [http://www.presencetypo.com/Pages-html/Intclas.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.presencetypo.com/Pages-html/Intclas.html)   
   
and previous ligature threads here on Typophile.

Anisette by Jean-Francois Porchez comes with some truely fascinating letterpairings:   
   
 [http://www.typofonderie.com/Alphabets/Anisette.asp](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.typofonderie.com/Alphabets/Anisette.asp)   
   
Good luck ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)

There was a font which won the Carter Prize at the previous Morisawa (not the one that just happened), and it had some amazing ligatures (in fact more like conflations of letters), but I forget what it was called (I don't think it's been released), and don't know where to point to, but I do remember it was by a French designer.   
   
hhp
Also, be sure to include all possible combinations of f and characters with diacritics, e.g. fj, f

Jonathan is right: go over all possibilities with the f overhang and other "clashing characters". For example, what's the use of making **fl** if you don't include **fb** , **fh** etc. Really, now the technical constraints are gone, it's all up to you.

I don't know of a complete listing. I think there isn't yet a   
font that explores _every_ ligature possibility.   
   
 [Mantinia](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/mantinia/mantiniacc/charmap.html) has some nice cap [examples](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/font_frames.tpl?cart=10432214612728759&fontname=Mantinia).   
   
 [Mrs. Eaves](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/emigre/mrs-eaves/) sports so many ligatures they are housed in   
seperate sets and sold with a [Ligature Maker](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/www.emigre.com/EFfeature.php?sp=142) app.   
   
And for an unconventional method of connecting letterforms   
see the inventive [Blue Island](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042445/http:/typography.net/type/b_island.htm).   
   
Most common ligatures (off the top of my head): fl, ff, fi, ffl, ffi

If you want to do something both innovative and functional, make your ligatures based on linguistic frequencies of letter-pairs (or even triplets).   
   
hhp
